scandal.question: Did I try to lead someone else into committing a sinful act?
scandal.description: Leading others to sin (also called "scandal") is sinful because it actively harms another person's soul by encouraging them away from God, making you spiritually responsible both for your own sin and for potentially damaging another's relationship with God.

scandal.question: Did you attempt to lead someone else into a sinful act through your actions?
scandal.description: Leading others to sin (also called "scandal") is sinful because it actively harms another person's soul by encouraging them away from God, making you spiritually responsible both for your own sin and for potentially damaging another's relationship with God.

impenitence.question: Have I held onto pride, refusing to acknowledge my wrongdoing?
impenitence.description: Impenitence is sinful because refusing to repent is a prideful rejection of God's mercy.

extracted_data_phrases: with the consequences of my actions
impenitence.question: Have I refused to acknowledge my wrongdoing against myself, even when confronted with the consequences of my actions?

impenitence.question: Have I held onto guilt for past wrongdoing, refusing to let go and seek forgiveness?

extracted_data_phrases: to someone who had wronged me

callousness.description: Refusing to forgive others is sinful because it contradicts Jesus's direct command to forgive and His example of mercy, while also blocking God's forgiveness of our own sins.

extracted_data_phrases: from someone who was suffering physically
callousness.question: Did you turn away from someone who was suffering physically?
callousness.description: This is sinful because it violates Jesus's direct command to care for the sick (Matthew 25:36) and fails to fulfill our fundamental Christian duty to show compassion and mercy to those who are suffering.

callousness.question: Did you turn away from someone who was sick, showing little concern for their well-being?
callousness.description: This is sinful because it violates Jesus's direct command to care for the sick (Matthew 25:36) and fails to fulfill our fundamental Christian duty to show compassion and mercy to those who are suffering.

blasphemy.question: Did I swear to God in anger, frustration, or during heated conversations?
blasphemy.description: This sin violates the Second Commandment by treating God's holy name with disrespect rather than reverence.

blasphemy.question: Did I use God's holy name in vain by swearing?
blasphemy.description: This sin violates the Second Commandment by treating God's holy name with disrespect rather than reverence.

blasphemy.question: Did I receive Holy Communion while being aware that my conscience was in disarray due to unresolved conflicts and unaddressed temptations within me?
blasphemy.description: This mortal sin is a form of sacrilege and profanes the real presence of Christ and shows grave disrespect for the sacrament by receiving unworthily.

blasphemy.description: This mortal sin is a form of sacrilege and profanes the real presence of Christ and shows grave disrespect for the sacrament by receiving unworthily.

autonomy.question: Did I take for granted the good things in my life, forgetting to acknowledge their source in God's providence?
autonomy.description: Believing that one's blessings are due to one's own self-sufficiency and determination is a sin as it is a rejection of recognizing Divine Providence as being ultimately responsible.
